column4: A multidimensional approach to impulsivity in Parkinson's disease: measurement and structural invariance of the UPPS Impulsive Behaviour Scale

column7: PwP-ICBs showed significantly higher impulsivity than HCs on all domains of the UPPS except sensation seeking. PwP+ICBs had significantly higher sensation seeking scores on the UPPS compared to PwP-ICBs. PwP made more risky decisions than HCs on Game of Dice task. In PwP, higher risk taking on the Game of Dice task is associated with lack of premeditation (UPPS) and longer disease duration, whereas lower risk taking is associated with lack of perseverance (UPPS). Disease duration is associated with lack of premeditation and lack of perseverance (both on the UPPS).

column4: Reward-learning and the novelty-seeking personality: A between- and within-subjects study of the effects of dopamine agonists on young Parkinson's patients
column5: (a) 26 de novo PwP (18 male), age 44.8 (5.2). UPDRS 30.8 (6.4), H&Y 1-3, duration since diagnosis 3.2 (2.0) months. (b) 22 medicated PwP (17 male). UPDRS 27.5 (6.1), H&Y 1-3, duration since diagnosis 8.8 (3.5) months. (c) 20 HC (15 male), age 45.3 (8.5).
column6: Probabilistic classification task (reward and punishment learning), Temperament and Character Inventory (personality traits). Also: commencement of medication.
column7: De novo PwP participants showed increased sensitivity to learning by punishment than medicated PwP participants, but less sensitivity to learning by reward. Compared to HCs, both PwP groups were impaired on reward learning, but de novo PwP outperformed HCs on learning by punishment. Medicated PwP participants had higher novelty seeking scores than HCs and de novo PwP. HCs had higher novelty seeking scores than de novo PwP. Positive correlation between novelty seeking and reward learning for medicated PwP. Positive correlation between punishment learning and harm avoidance for HCs. After commencing DA agonist treatment, the newly medicated (previously de novo) PwP group showed improved reward learning, disrupted punishment learning, and increased novelty seeking. They performed similarly to HCs for reward learning, but worse for punishment learning.

Suggests medication and DBS independently contribute to more advantageous behaviour, but no significant interaction of the two. No effect of medication or DBS on the use of negative feedback to make more advantageous decisions.

column6: Pro-saccade task (automatic saccade), anti-saccade task (saccadic response inhibition).
column7: PwP were slower than HC in the anti-saccade task but not the pro-saccade task, regardless of whether it was the gap (delay between fixation and target) or overlap (fixation remained with target onset) condition. column4: L-Dopa medication remediates cognitive inflexibility, but increases impulsivity in patients with Parkinson's disease

No switch cost differences between PwP and HCs generally, but switch costs were greater OFF compared to HCs but no diffs ON. In the CGT there were no differences between HCs and PwPs, or when ON vs OFF medication, for quality of decision making and deliberation time measures. column4: Reversal learning in Parkinson's disease depends on medication status and outcome valence

For PwP ON meds, there was a higher error rate on reversal learning switch trials for unexpected punishment than unexpected reward (i.e. a reduced sensitivity to punishment vs reward). For HCs andPwP OFF meds, there were no significant differences in error rate between unexpected punishment and unexpected reward on switch trials. No significant differences between HCs and either PwP ON or PwP OFF for valence (reward/punishment) on switch trials.

column4: Supervisory and routine processes in noun and verb generation in nondemented patients with Parkinson's disease

For noun production, PwP participants performed better (higher accuracy, reduced RT) when there was a strong association rather than a weak one, but HCs performed no differently. For verb production, both groups performed better (higher accuracy, reduced RT) when there was a strong association rather than a weak one.

PAG – PwP+dementia showed riskier decision making when they had a low probability of winning, compared to PwP and HC, but no differences when there was a high probability of winning.

column6: Stroop (response inhibition).

column5: (a) 8 vascular PwP (7 male), 78 (2). (b) 27 idiopathic PwP (18 male), 80 (5). (c) 27 HC (19 male), 78 (3).
column6: Stroop task (inhibitory abilities). Also: fMRI.
column7: Significant differences between groups for interference errors and interference RT. Vascular PwP had higher interference errors and worse interference RT than HC. No comparisons between HC and idiopathic PwP. Abnormal increased resting state activity in perigenual anterior cingulate cortex not suppressed during the task resulting in impaired inhibitory control on Stroop.

column4: Impulsive oculomotor action selection in Parkinson's disease
column6: Saccadic Simon task (impulsive action selection and suppression), Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (trait impulsivity).
column7: PwP showed a greater congruency effect and had more errors on incongruent trials compared to HC, but no differences for errors on congruent trials. PwP were also faster generally. PwP group showed increased impulsive action compared to HC, but PwP and HC were equally proficient at selective inhibition. PwP and HCs did not differ on total BIS scores (no comparisons for subscores). In HCs there is no correlation between trait impulsivity and impulsive action/selective inhibition. In PwP there are correlations between trait impulsivity and performance on the Simon task. Specifically, greater impulsive fast errors are associated with higher trait impulsivity, as well as cognitive and motor subscores. Additionally, more proficient inhibition at the slow end of the response time distribution is associated with higher total and cognitive trait scores. Congruency effect, impulsive action, and selective inhibition are not associated with disease duration, disease severity, or levodopa dose in PwP

No significant differences in action suppression pre- and post- CSAI.

column4: Theory of Mind Deficits in Parkinson's Disease: A Product of Executive Dysfunction?
column6: Stroop (inhibition).
column7: PwP made significantly more errors than HC. No difference in RT interference effects between PwP and HC. Used a task with black and white squares (no words) and participants had to say the opposite colour to the one presented.

column4: The impact of Parkinson's disease and subthalamic deep brain stimulation on reward processing
column5: (a) 33 PwP with STN-DBS (23 male), 65.88 (6.40). UPDRS ON DBS 9.05 (9.81), UPDRS OFF DBS 33.29 (14.01), H&Y 3.17 (0.51), duration 15.27 years (5.37). No significant difference between groups for total gains on IGT. PwP STN-DBS patients chose less advantageously ON versus OFF. STN-DBS patients with it ON chose less advantageously than non DBS patients and HCs. No significant differences in learning across the task. column4: Theory of mind and joint action in Parkinson’s disease

column6: Calculation task

column5: (a) 15 PwP (11 male), 60 (7). UPDRS OFF medication 21 (14-32), ON medication 7 (0-20), H&Y 3 (0), duration 12 years (6).

column4: Subthalamic nucleus stimulation, dopaminergic treatment and impulsivity in Parkinson's disease
column5: 16 PwP (12 male), 64 (8). UPDRS ON DBS/ON meds 7 (2-20), UPDRS ON DBS/OFF meds 12 (3-24), UPDRS OFF DBS/ON meds 24 (7-58), UPDRS OFF DBS/OFF meds 35 (13-70).

column7: No significant interactions between DBS/meds/congruency for RT or accuracy. RT shorter for congruent than incongruent, when DBS was ON versus OFF, and when medication was ON versus OFF. Accuracy higher for congruent than incongruent, and when DBS was ON versus OFF, no differences for medication. CAFs: Accuracy was reduced for fast responses on incongruent trials moreso when DBS was ON.  No other significant findings for bin/DBS/meds/congruency. Delta plots: No significant interactions between bin/congruency/DBS/meds. Partial subthreshold EMG errors: No significant interactions between DBS/meds/congruency, but more frequent on incongruent vs congruent as expected. Partial subthreshold EMG errors: correction ratio reduced (got worse) when DBS was ON vs OFF, and when meds were ON vs OFF. No significant interactions. DBS affected motor and pre-motor time, whereas medication only affected motor time.

column4: Dopamine modulation of intertemporal decision-making: Evidence from parkinson disease

No differences in the Go version of the task – group differences only occur when trials requiring inhibition occur infrequently (as in the No-Go version) compared to frequently (as in the Go version).

column4: The effects of unilateral versus bilateral subthalamic nucleus deep brain stimulation on prosaccades and antisaccades in Parkinson's disease

PwP: Negative correlation between posterior cingulate cortex and left medial temporal lobe connectivity and accuracy of visually guided reactive saccades. No correlations between other behavioural measures and connectivity strengths.

No correlations between FA values and any eye movement variables in PwP.

column4: Novelty Seeking in Patients with Right-Versus Left-Onset Parkinson Disease
column6: Temperament and Character Inventory (personality traits).
column7: Right onset PwP scored higher on novelty seeking (more impulsive) than left onset PwP. No differences between right and left onset PwP for harm avoidance or self-directedness.

column4: Inhibitory Control During Smooth Pursuit in Parkinson's Disease and Huntington's Disease
column6: Saccadic smooth pursuit task (inhibitory control).
column7: PwP made more erroneous saccadic errors towards the distractor stimuli than HCs.

column4: Disinhibition of automatic word reading in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 8 late onset PwP (8 male), 69.5. H&Y 3.25, duration 10.6 years. (b) 8 older HCs (8 male), 70.6. (c) 12 early onset PwP (8 male), 46.5. H&Y 2, duration 8.9 years. (d) 13 younger HCs (8 male), 42.6.
column6: Stroop (inhibition of cognitive processes).
column7: Interference effect (RTs): no differences. Facilitation effect (RTs): reduced facilitation in patients overall compared to HCs. Errors: PwP more errors than HC overall. Facilitatory effects similar in all groups. Interference effect larger in late onset (could be due to higher disease severity as evidenced by H&Y, or global cognitive impairment as evidenced by lower MMSE scores).

column4: Dopaminergic therapy affects learning and impulsivity in Parkinson's disease
column6: Stimulus-response association learning
column7: PwP participants were slower to learn stimulus-response associations ON versus OFF meds. No significant differences between PwP and HC in the learning phase. “Stimulus-response association learning spared in PwP but impaired by meds”. No differences in accuracy between PwP and HC in the test phase. No significant differences in facilitation effect (associated with impulsivity) of congruent/incongruent trials in PwP and HC, or ON and OFF meds. No significant differences in interference effect of congruent/incongruent trials in PwP and HC, or ON and OFF meds.

column4: Intact Reward Learning but Elevated Delay Discounting in Parkinson's Disease Patients With Impulsive-Compulsive Spectrum Behaviors
column6: Salience Attribution Test (value learning), Kirby delayed discounting questionnaire (impulsiveness/tolerance to delay).
column7: PwP+ICB patients showed higher k than both PwP-ICB and HCs. There were no differences between PwP-ICB and HCs. PwP-ICBs demonstrated impaired stimulus-reward learning compared to PwP+ICBs and HCs, who did not differ. There is a double dissociation between reward learning and delay discounting in PwP+ICBs/PwP-ICBs.

column4: Influence of promised rewards on conflict resolution in healthy participants and patients with Parkinson's disease
column6: Rewarded Simon task (impulsive action selection/selective inhibition).
column7: Overall (non-rewarded) RT congruency effect was higher for PwP than HC, but accuracy congruency effect equal. Promised reward increased the congruency effect in HC, but not PwP. Promised rewards had no effect on impulsive action selection in PwP patients or HCs. PwP patients had greater difficulty inhibiting inappropriate responses compared to HC. Selective inhibition in PwP patients was modulated by promised reward.

column4: Cognitive and motor components of response speed in the Stroop test in Parkinson's disease patients
column6: Stroop task (response inhibition).
column7: PwP patients showed reduced response inhibition compared to HCs.

column4: Different effects of dopaminergic medication on perceptual decision-making in Parkinson's disease as a function of task difficulty and speed-accuracy instructions
column6: Moving Dots Task (impulsive decision-making). Also: medication ON/OFF.
column7: Higher difficulty paradigm, RTs and errors: No group or medication differences for RT on correct trials, but higher error rate and longer RTs on errors for PwP ON compared to HCs. Higher difficulty paradigm, drift diffusion: Drift rate was lower for PwP compared to HC both when ON or OFF medication. Drift rates OFF medication were higher compared to drift rates ON medication. No differences for boundary separation (response threshold) or non-decision time between PwP or HCs nor when ON or OFF medication. Speed or accuracy emphasis, RTs and errors: PwP patients were slower  on correct trials than HCs, and PwP OFF medication made more errors and were slower on error trials than HCs. There were no effects of medication. Speed or accuracy emphasis, drift diffusion: PwP patients had lower drift rates than HCs but no effect of medication. Mean response thresholds were higher for PwP patients compared to HCs (no interaction effect with speed vs accuracy instructions), but no effect of medication. No effect of group on non-decision time but non-decision time was higher when OFF compared to ON medication.

column4: Sensorimotor subthalamic stimulation restores risk-reward trade-off in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 11 PwP (9 male), 62 (6.4). UPDRS ON 14.6 (4.6), UPDRS OFF 36.4 (9.1), duration 11.5 years (4.2). (b) 11 HC (9 male), 63.5 (7.4).
column6: Emotional Stroop (conflict adaptation). Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: Significant conflict induced slowing (i.e. significantly different from zero) in PwP OFF and HCs, but not PwP ON. Stroop effect much bigger for negative vs positive valence in DBS OFF, but no difference in valence for PwP ON or HCs. Accuracy extremely high for all groups so not analysed.

column4: Subthalamic nucleus stimulation impairs emotional conflict adaptation in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 17 STN-DBS PwP (11 male), 64.94 (7.03). UPDRS OFF DBS 35 (11), UPDRS ON DBS 17 (11), duration 14.23 years (7.50). (b) 17 HC, 65.64 (6.78).
column6: Barratt Impulsiveness Scale, decision-making task (reward and risk). Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: HCs showed a neutral level of risk that optimised gains throughout the task. PwP STN-DBS patients were significantly more risk averse than HCs when OFF STN-DBS but this significantly increased to a more normal level of  neutral risk when ON, which was then not significantly different to HCs. Mean overall gain reflected the pattern above. It was similar between HCs and patients when DBS was ON, but reduced compared to both when DBS was OFF. HCs and PwP patients both ON and OFF STN-DBS showed similar response slowing with an increased accumulated sum.

column4: The relationship between impulsivity and impulse control disorders in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 14 PwP+ICB (7  male), 60 (9). UPDRS 16.7 (6), duration 9 years (5). (b) 36 PwP-ICB (24 male), 65 (9). UPDRS 18.8 (6.4), duration 8 years (5). (c) 100 HC (47 male), 61 (9).
column6: Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (impulsivity).
column7: PwP participants (both groups) had higher BIS scores than HCs (both groups). PwP+ICB had higher BIS scores than PwP-ICB.

column4: Impairment in the intention formation and execution phases of prospective memory in Parkinson's disease
column6: Stroop (inhibition).
column7: PwP made more errors compared to HC.

column4: Impaired inhibitory oculomotor control in patients with Parkinson's disease
column6: Saccadic Redirect Task (inhibitory control)
column7: Target switch reaction time (analogous to SSRT) was longer for PwP than HC = reduced inhibitory control in oculomotor stopping.

column4: Orienting attention in aging and Parkinson's disease: Distinguishing modes of control
column6: Reflexive Covert Orienting (inhibition of return), Saccadic Volitional Overt Orienting (controlled prosaccade), Saccadic Reflexive Overt Orienting (automatic prosaccade), Antisaccade/Volitional and Reflexive Overt Orienting (suppression of automatic saccade, initiation of controlled saccade).
column7: Reflexive covert (manual task with peripheral indicator): No main effect of group on manual RTs, but for all groups latencies were shorter when SOA increased and RT was longer for cued than uncued when SOA was longer (inhibition of return effect). No significant effects for accuracy data. Covert reflexive orienting (with regard to inhibition of return) equal across groups. Volitional overt (prosaccade with central indicator): YC faster than PwP and OC, but no differences between PwP and OC. PwP undershot the target more than YC and OC. Reflexive overt (prosaccade with peripheral indicator): PwP significantly faster than OC. Saccades were generally faster when fixation disappeared vs staying on screen. PwP and OC made more errors than YC. Antisaccade (combo of reflexive and volitional overt): YC faster than PwP and OC, but no differences between PwP and OC. No significant effect of group for accuracy data. PwP showed faster RTs in reflexive overt, and slower than YC (but not OC) in volitional overt, but this wasn’t reflected in antisaccade task (which is a combo of the two, and therefore each effect confounds the other).

column4: Planning and realisation of complex intentions in patients with Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 16 PwP OFF medication (11 male), 61.1 (6.9). Duration 4.81 years (3). (b) 16 HC (11 male), 62.6 (9.1).
column6: Stroop Task (inhibition).
column7: Higher RT interference effect for PwP than HC.

column4: Dopaminergic influences on risk preferences of parkinson's disease patients
column6: Economic choice task (risk preferences). Also: medication ON/OFF.
column7: All groups were generally risk averse (PwP+ICB/PwP-ICB/HC, ON and OFF meds). Certainty equivalent (subjective value of a gamble) showed more risk taking in the ON state when expected values were higher. Relative risk aversion was similar amongst HC and PwP ON and OFF medication, but there was a significant decrease in risk aversion when ON compared to OFF. There was no main effect of ICB for risk aversion.

column4: Neuropsychological and emotional correlates of personality traits in Parkinson's disease
column6: Temperament and Character Inventory (personality traits), Stroop Task (inhibition), Trail Making Test (cognitive flexibility), Odd Man Out (cognitive flexibility).
column7: PwP showed higher harm avoidance than healthy controls, but no difference on novelty seeking, reward dependence, or persistence. No differences on Stroop interference RT index or Trail Making Test B. PwP made more errors on Odd Man Out task.

column4: In Parkinson's disease pallidal deep brain stimulation speeds up response initiation but has no effect on reactive inhibition
column6: Conditional Stop Signal task (reactive inhibition and conflict resolution). Also: Globus pallidus interna DBS ON/OFF.
column7: No difference in SSRT between PwP and HC, nor ON or OFF GPi-DBS. No difference in conflict induced slowing between PwP and HC, nor ON or OFF GPi-DB. Response delay effect worse in PwP than HC only when GPi-DBS was ON.

column4: In Parkinson's disease STN stimulation enhances responsiveness of movement initiation speed to high reward value
column6: Rewarded Reaction Time. Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF.

column4: Cognitive performance correlates with the degree of dopaminergic degeneration in the associative part of the striatum in non-demented Parkinson's patients
column5: (a) 16 PwP, 62.1 (11.6). UPDRS ON 11.3 (6.7), UPDRS OFF 25.1 (10.1), duration 4.5 years (4.1).
column6: Stroop (selective inhibition). Also: Medication ON/OFF, [123I]FP-CIT SPECT.
column7: Interference effect was significantly greater when OFF medication compared to ON. No difference in committed errors. Interference effect did not show any correlations with striatal dopamine transporter (DAT) decline. Authors conclude their imaging method isn’t sensitive enough.

column4: Motivational Sensitivities Linked to Impulsive Motor Errors in Parkinson's Disease
column6: Simon task, Delis-Kaplan Trail Making Test
column7: Accuracy Simon effect was larger for PwP than HC, but no differences for RT Simon effect. Fast impulsive errors were similar between HC and PwP. PwP were less effective at inhibiting at the slow end of the RT distribution compared to HC. They then split some of the PwP group by low/high scores on the Behavioural Inhibition System questionnaire. Accuracy Simon effect was larger for low BIS PwP than high BIS PwP, but no differences for RT Simon effect. More fast impulsive errors for low BIS PwP compared to high BIS PwP. Inhibition at the slow end of the RT distribution similar between low and high BIS PwP groups. DK analogous to TMT-B scores were no different between low BIS PwP and high BIS PwP

column4: Dopaminergic influences on executive function and impulsive behaviour in impulse control disorders in Parkinson's disease
column6: Stop Signal task (response inhibition), Delay Discounting task (delay discounting), Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (BIS). Also: catechol-O-methyl transferase genotyping, medication ON/OFF.
column7: No differences in response inhibition between PwP+ICB, PwP-ICB, and HC (no SSRT examined) in the ON state based on commission errors (no SSD was used so no SSRT). Higher delay discounting rate (more impulsive) for PwP+ICB group vs PwP-ICB group, which didn't differ in the ON vs OFF states. PwP more impulsive than HC generally. Higher BIS scores (more impulsive) for PwP+ICB group than PwP-ICB group and HC group. PwP group as a whole were more impulsive ON medication compared to HC. No differences in impulsivity for COMT groups.

column4: Distractibility with advancing age and Parkinson's disease
column6: Distractor Inteference Task (eye tracking).
column7: PwP were slower than HC. No SOA effects between groups. Positive compatibility effect greater for PwP than HC (more hyper-distractibility). Compatibility effects did not significantly decrease as SOA increased in people with PwP – suggests impairment of distractor inhibition (this was not directly compared with HCs though).

column4: Levodopa improves response inhibition and enhances striatal activation in early-stage Parkinson's disease
column6: Stop Signal Task (response inhibition). Also: fMRI, medication ON/OFF.
column7: SSRT significantly longer for PwP OFF meds compared to PwP ON and HCs. No significant differences between PwP ON and HCs. PwP OFF showed lower saliency related activations in the right striatum compared to HCs and PwP ON, and lower activations in the thalamus IFG, and insular cortices compared to PwP ON. No significant differences in activation between successful and failed stops between any groups.

column4: Decision and dopaminergic system: An ERPs study of Iowa gambling task in Parkinson's disease
column6: Iowa Gambling Task (decision making). Also: EEG.
column7: PwP participants preferred disadvantageous decks whereas HC preferred advantageous decks overall. No correlation between total score on IGT and disease duration, age of onset, motor UPDRS score. PwP patients did not learn over time as well as the HC group to pick the advantageous decks. ERPs suggest abnormal feedback processing in PwP – did not show differences in ERPs for positive or negative feedback.

column4: Lack of inhibition in Parkinson's disease: evidence from a lexical decision task
column5: (a) Semantic priming: 10 PwP (5 male), 65.4 (9.0). (b) Semantic priming: 17 HC (7 male), 69.1 (7.9). (c) Repetition priming: 7 PwP (2 male), 64.6 (10.8). (d) Repetition priming: 17 HC (8 male), 66.8 (9.4).
column6: Semantic Priming Task (activation and inhibition of words), Repetition Priming Task (priming and inhibition).
column7: Semantic priming: No significant group effects for switch cost or facilitation effect. PwP group showed positive priming but HC group did not, suggests PwP are unable to inhibit irrelevant distractors. Repetition priming: HCs showed negative priming effect whereas PwP showed comparatively reduced negative priming which suggests difficulty inhibiting responses.

column4: Parkinson's Disease: Impulsivity Does Not Cause Impulse Control Disorders but Boosts Their Severity
column6: Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (impulsivity), PEBL Continuous Performance Test (motor inhibition)
column7: No significant differences between groups for BIS total score, or attentional, motor, and non-planning scores. No significant differences between groups for commission errors on the CPT. Both BIS scores and CPT errors were significantly correlated with QUIPs scores in the PwP+ICB group.

column4: Risky decision-making and affective features of impulse control disorders in Parkinson’s disease
column6: Balloon Analogue Risk Task (risky decision making), Trail Making Test (set shifting), Kirby delay discounting (temporal discounting), Go/No-Go (motor inhibitory control), Hayling Test (verbal inhibitory control), Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (impulsiveness).
column7: (a) No significant group differences for average adjusted number of pumps. (b) HC and PwP-ICB groups reduced their average pumps following negative feedback whereas PwP+ICB didn’t. (c) No significant group differences for errors on the TMT-B, Kirby total score, GNG commission errors, Hayling section 2 scaled score, or BIS.

column4: Dysfunctional action control as a specific feature of Parkinson's disease
column6: Cued Go/No-Go (habit formation). Also: levodopa ON/OFF
column7: HC and PwP+OFF failed to inhibit responses in No-Go in deconditioning phase compared to PwP+ON. Failure for PwP+ON to learn in conditioning phase?

column4: Modulation of Habit Formation by Levodopa in Parkinson's Disease
column5: (a) 11 mild motor impairment PwP (7 male), 70.1 (4.1). UPDRS 13.7 (4.2), H&Y 1.6 (0.6), duration 5.9 years (2.8). (b) 11 advanced motor impairment PwP (5 male), 74.3 (4.9). UPDRS 39 (6.8), H&Y 2.8 (0.6), duration 7.5 years (3.2). (c) 11 PwP with dementia (8 male), 76.2 (8.8). UPDRS 41.1 (3.8), H&Y 3.0 (0.6), duration 10.8 years (5.2). (d) 11 Alzheimer’s disease patients (3 male), 77.1 (8.3). (e) 11 HC (4 male), 72.4 (8.0).
column6: Go/No-Go (action control).
column7: PwP patients with dementia showed reduced inhibitory control (more commission errors) compared to the other groups. PwP patients with advanced motor impairment showed reduced inhibitory control (more commission errors) compared to HCs only in the task where switches were made between hands. PwP patients with advanced motor impairment or dementia showed more omission errors (over inhibition?) than HCs. Commission and omission errors were correlated with increased gait and postural instability problems. Total UPDRS score was correlated with commission errors.

column4: Using virtual reality to explore the role of conflict resolution and environmental salience in Freezing of Gait in Parkinson's disease
column6: VR Stroop task (conflict resolution).
column7: Footstep latency longer on high conflict trials in PwP+FOG compared to PwP-FOG and HCs, but no group differences on  neutral or low conflict trials. Same true for trials with high visuospatial processing, therefore conflict resolution impairment could be due to increased processing requirement in PwP+FOG.

column4: Apathy in Parkinson's disease: an electrophysiological study
column5: (a) 10 PwP+apathy, 67.4. UPDRS ON 11.6, UPDRS OFF 28.8. (b) 15 PwP-apathy, 61.9. UPDRS ON 8.3, UPDRS OFF 23.9.
column6: Stroop task (inhibitory control). Also: Dopaminergic medication ON/OFF.
column7: No differences between PwP+apathy and PwP-apathy both ON and OFF medication. Stroop performance not correlated with apathy score ON or OFF medication.

column4: Taq1A polymorphism and medication effects on inhibitory action control in Parkinson disease
column5: (a) 11 AA/AG rs1800497 PwP (8 male), 60 (1.9). UPDRS 17.5 (2.3), duration 6.3 years (1.8). (b) 14 GG rs1800497 PwP (6 male), 63.2 (1.9). UPDRS 15.9 (2.3), duration 7.9 years (1.6). (c) 18 CC/CT rs6277 PwP (10 male), 62 (1.7). UPDRS 15.9 (1.9), duration 7 years (1.4). (d) 7 TT rs6277 PwP (4 male), 61.3 (2.5). UPDRS 18.4 (2.9), duration 7.6 (2.6). (e) 11 CC/CT rs6280 PwP (9 male), 61.2 (2). UPDRS 20.4 (2), duration 9 years (2.12). (f) 13 TT rs6280 PwP (4 male), 62.8 (2). UPDRS 13.4 (2.3), duration 5.8 years (1.4).
column6: Simon task (inhibitory control). Also: medication ON/OFF.
column7: DRD2 rs1800497: no effect of polymorphism or medication for RT, accuracy, or response capture. Those with the A allele showed a more negative going slope (better inhibition) ON vs OFF medication, whereas those without the A allele (and with the G allele) showed the opposite, with a more negative going slope OFF than ON medication. DRD2 rs6277: no effect of polymorphism or medication for RT, accuracy, response capture, or inhibitory control. DRD3 rs6280: no effect of polymorphism or medication for RT, accuracy, response capture, or inhibitory control.

column4: Assessing Cognitive Impairment in Parkinson's Disease: A Comparison of Two Tower Tasks
column6: Delis-Kaplan Colour-Word Interference Test/Stroop task (inhibition)
column7: PwP showed reduced inhibition and reduced inhibition in the inhibition switching version. Inhibition and inhibition switching ability in PwP was related to CANTAB Tower of London performance, and inhibition ability in PwP was related to Delis-Kaplan Tower of Hanoi performance. This was not true for the HCs.

column4: Impulse control behaviors and subthalamic deep brain stimulation in Parkinson disease
column5: (a) 113 PwP no ICB (60 male). UPDRS pre-DBS 15.5 (7.8), UPDRS post-DBS 19.2 (11.7). (b) 18 PwP remitting ICB (15 male). UPDRS pre-DBS 14.1 (7.8), UPDRS post-DBS 18.7 (11.4). (c) 8 PwP persistent ICB (8 male). UPDRS pre-DBS 14.3 (6.7), UPDRS post-DBS 16.5 (8.7). (d) 11 PwP new-onset ICB (3 male). UPDRS pre-DBS 13.4 (4.2), UPDRS post-DBS 18.9 (10.1).
column6: Trail Making Test. Also: pre/post STN-DBS.
column7: No significant differences on TMT A or TMT B between baseline (pre-DBS) and follow-up (post-DBS), nor between new-onset, remitting, persistent, and no ICB groups.

column4: Intertemporal Choice in Parkinson's Disease
column5: (a) 17 PwP (25 male), 60.6 (7.6). UPDRS ON medication 18.4 (7.4), UPDRS OFF medication 28.0 (8.1), H&Y ON medication 2.15 (0.39), H&Y OFF medication 2.6 (0.4), duration 4.4 years (3.4). (b) 17 HC (10 male), 59.8 (7.0).
column6: Intertemporal Choice task (delay discounting). Also: Medication ON/OFF.
column7: PwP patients presented similar delay discounting rates both ON and OFF medication. PwP patients had higher discounting rates (were more impulsive) than HCs when medication was ON. Delay discounting rates in PwP were not correlated with medication dosage, symptom severity scores, or disease duration.

column4: Deep Brain Stimulation of Subthalamic Nuclei Affects Arm Response Inhibition In Parkinson's Patients
column6: Countermanding reaching task/Stop Signal task (response inhibition). Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF, medication ON/OFF.
column7: NB: same task and participants as in Mirabella et al (2013) but with 2 fewer patients. Reduced inhibitory control (longer SSRT) when STN-DBS was OFF, and significantly better inhibitory control (shorter SSRT) when both left and right STN-DBS was ON. PwP showed reduced inhibitory control compared to HCs when STN-DBS was OFF, but performed just as well as HCs when STN-DBS was ON.

column4: Stimulation of Subthalamic Nuclei Restores a Near Normal Planning Strategy in Parkinson's Patients
column6: Countermanding Task/Stop Signal Task (proactive control). Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF, medication ON/OFF.
column7: NB: same task and participants as in Mirabella et al (2012) but with 2 extra patients. HCs and DBS ON all showed longer RTs and shorter MTs in no-stop vs go-only. DBS OFF both RT and MT longer in no-stop than go-only. In PwP group, MTs of go-only trials didn’t differ between OFF and ON but MTs of no-stop trials were faster for ON vs OFF. HCs had longer MTs in go-only trials than no-stop trials, but DBS OFF had the opposite (MTs in no-stop trials longer than in go-only trials). Accuracy of responding similar between groups and within DBS conditions (even though faster MTs usually result in a loss of accuracy). DBS improves planning strategies (proactive control).

column4: Inhibitory control is not lateralized in Parkinson's patients
column5: (a) 20 PwP with right dominant symptoms (13 male), 61.4 (8.89). UPDRS 17.8, H&Y 2.23 (0.38). (b) 20 PwP with left dominant symptoms (11 male), 63.85 (5.08). UPDRS 19.3 (4.77), H&Y 2.3 (0.44). (c) 20 HC (10 male), 61 (5.7).
column6: Countermanding task (inhibitory control)
column7: SSRT was significantly longer for both right and left lateralised PwP patients compared to HCs, but there were no difference between left and right dominant symptom patients. Inhibitory control not lateralised in PwP patients. Longer RTs and shorter MTs in no-stop compared to go-only between groups and within DBS conditions. Accuracy similar across groups and within DBS conditions. Context effect is expected to be: longer RTs for no-stop compared to go-only trials, and short MTs for no-stop compared to go-only trials. True for HC, but not for PwP where a greater number of participants had a reversed or no context effect (no diff between left and right lateralised).

column4: Cognitive rehabilitation in Parkinson's disease: evidence from neuroimaging
column6: Stroop (attention). Also: fMRI.
column7: PwP patients were slower to respond but no differences in errors (no interference effect calculated). HCs showed more brain activation than PwPs whilst doing the Stroop task in: left precentral gyrus, left medial frontal gyrus, right precuneus, left inferior parietal gyrus.

column4: Multiple Modes of Impulsivity in Parkinson's Disease
column6: Kirby Temporal Discounting task (delay discounting), Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (impulsivity), Behavioural Inhibitory System/Behavioural Approach System (appetite motivation/aversive motivation), Motor Go/No-Go task (action restraint), Temporal Interval Estimation (impulsivity), Frontal Assessment Battery with Go/No-Go (motor inhibitory control), Stop Signal Task (action cancellation), Cambridge Gambling Task (risk-taking), Hayling Sentence Completion (sentence completion), Stroop test (conflict resolution), Saccade Go/No-Go (saccadic inhibition).
column7: PwP were significantly more impulsive, or showed reduced inhibitory control, compared to HC on all tasks except the temporal discounting and gambling tasks.

column4: A novel bedside task to tap inhibitory dysfunction and fronto-striatal atrophy in Parkinson's disease
column6: Excluded Letter Fluency test, Hayling test.
column7: PwP patients performed worse than HCs in terms of rule violations in ELF, and inhibition errors on the Hayling test (but no diff on scaled score). Rule violations on the ELF in PwP were related to grey matter atrophy in medial orbitofrontal cortex, left inferior frontal gyrus, and right nucleus accumbens.

column4: Deficits in inhibitory control and conflict resolution on cognitive and motor tasks in Parkinson's disease
column6: Conditional Stop Signal task (response inhibition/response conflict), Stroop (response inhibition), Random number generation (inhibition of competing responses), Hayling sentence completion (response suppression/inhibition).
column7: PwP patients had longer SSRT than HCs. Conflict induced slowing (Go-RT noncrit Stop trials – Go-RT noncrit Go trials) effect was greater in PwP than HC. PwP performed worse in the Hayling test than HC for both B-A and scaled score. PwP performed worse on Stroop task than HC (higher RT interference effect, more uncorrected errors on interference trials). PwP worse than HC on random number generation.

column4: Levodopa medication does not influence motor inhibition or conflict resolution in a conditional stop-signal task in Parkinson's disease
column6: Conditional Stop Signal task (motor inhibition & conflict resolution). Also: Medication ON/OFF.
column7: SSRT similar when ON vs OFF medication, but PwP worse than HC both ON and OFF meds. No differences in conflict induced slowing between PwP and HC, whether ON or OFF meds.

column4: Bilateral stimulation of the subthalamic nucleus has differential effects on reactive and proactive inhibition and conflict-induced slowing in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 15 PwP (13 male), 58.93 (6.5). UPDRS ON STN-DBS 14.69 (6.8), UPDRS OFF STN-DBS 25.46 (6.4), duration 13.47 years (4.2). (b) 29 HC (15 male), 56.97 (6.9).
column6: Conditional Stop Signal task (response inhibition & conflict resolution). Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: SSRT worse when ON vs OFF STN-DBS. PwP had longer SSRT than HC only when STN-DBS was ON rather than OFF. No differences in conflict induced slowing between PwP and HC, nor between STN-DBS ON and OFF. Response delay effect  worse for PwP then HC only when STN-DBS was OFF. No differences between OFF and ON in PwP.

column4: The subthalamic nucleus and inhibitory control: Impact of subthalamotomy in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 10 right subthalamotomy PwP, 52.70 (8.4). UPDRS OFF post-surgery 22.82 (7.1), duration 11.7 years (3.6). (b) 12 left subthalamotomy PwP, 51.58. UPDRS OFF post-surgery 25 (5.5), duration 9.78 (4.6). (c) 14 unoperated PwP, 58.74 (5.1). UPDRS OFF 39.92 (9.9), duration 7.53 years (3.7). (d) 23 HC, 55 (6.1).
column6: Conditional Stop Signal task (response inhibition & conflict resolution).
column7: All patients groups showed reduced inhibitory control (longer SSRT) compared to HCs, and left subthalamotomy patients showed better inhibitory control compared to noperated PwP patients. Unoperated PwP patients showed greater conflict induced slowing compared to HCs and left subthalamotomy patients, but the right and left subthalamotomy patients showed similar conflict resolution to HCs. Right subthalamtomy patients showed worse response delay effect than HCs, but no other group differences.

column4: Unilateral subthalamotomy in Parkinson's disease: Cognitive, psychiatric and neuroimaging changes
column5: 14 PwP (12 male), 55.21 (7.3). UPDRS pre 42 (8.9), UPDRS post 23 (5.46), duration 10.35 years (3.1).
column6: Hayling Test (response initiation/suppression), Delis-Kaplan Stroop (inhibition/switching), Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (impulsivity), FAB Go/No-Go (inhibitory control). Also: MRI, pre/post STN-DBS surgery.
column7: No significant differences in Stroop performance before vs after surgery or for left vs right lesions (inhibition errors, interference RT). Surgery caused a significant improvement in type B errors (somewhat related to the meaning of the sentence rather than actually connected to the meaning of the sentence) on the Hayling Test for left lesions but not right. No significant differences for total score. No significant differences before/after surgery for left or right lesions on the Barratt Impulsiveness Scale. Bigger reductions in LEDD after surgery was significantly associated with lower impulsivity on the BIS. Larger STN lesions were associated with increased impulsivity (a greater change in BIS scores before vs after surgery). Positive correlation between BIS scores and right STN lesion size, but not left STN lesion size. No significant difference before/after surgery or for left/right lesions on inhibitory control on FAB GNG.

column4: Anti-saccades predict cognitive functions in older adults and patients with Parkinson's disease
column6: Pro-/anti-saccade task (task switching/inhibitory control).
column7: No group differences for pro-saccade RT or errors. PwP had more anti-saccade errors than YC, but not OC. No significant group differences for anti-saccade RT.

column4: Controlled study of decision-making and cognitive impairment in Parkinson's disease
column6: Iowa Gambling Task, Stroop.
column7: Total IGT scores were significantly lower than the HC group. PwP patients did not learn to pick advantageously over time, but HC did. No relationship between total IGT scores and type of medication, dosage, PwP duration, severity of disease. No differences between patients on stable response vs fluctuating response to meds. No relationship between Stroop performance and IGT (but group differences on Stroop not reported).

column4: Deep Brain Stimulation of the Internal Globus Pallidus Improves Response Initiation and Proactive Inhibition in Patients With Parkinson's Disease
column5: (a) 14 PwP+DBS (5 male), 64 (8). H&Y ON 2.6 (0.5), H&Y OFF 2.9 (0.7), duration 9 years (3). (b) 13 PwP-DBS (9 male), 66 (7). H&Y 2.2 (0.4), duration 8 (3). (c) 15 HC (7 male), 65 (7).
column6: Stop Signal Task (inhibitory control). Also: GPi-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: No significant difference in SSRT (reactive inhibition) between GPi-DBS ON vs OFF, nor between DBS patients (whether ON or OFF) and medicated non-DBS patients and HCs. Proactive inhibition was greater when GPi-DBS was ON vs OFF, and compared to non-DBS patients. Non-DBS patients showed significantly less proactive inhibition than HCs.

column4: Punding in non-demented Parkinson's disease patients: Relationship with psychiatric and addiction spectrum comorbidity
column5: (a) 11 PwP+PG (8 male), 64.9 (10.9). UPDRS 20.4 (12.3), duration 8.3 years (3.2). (b) 23 PwP+ICB (18 male), 62 (9.1). UPDRS 18.4 (8.5), duration 8.8 years (6). (c) 120 PwP-ICB (60 male), 67.7 (9.4). UPDRS 20.4 (8.4), duration 7 years (5.4).
column6: Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (trait impulsivity), Snaith-Hamilton Pleasure Scale (anhedonia).
column7: Total BIS score higher for PwP+PG than PwP+ICB and PwP-ICB. Total Snaith-Hamilton Pleasure Scale score higher for PwP+PG than PwP+ICB and PwP-ICB, suggesting a reduced ability to gain pleasure from rewarding activities (anhedonia).

column4: Anhedonia in Parkinson's disease patients with and without pathological gambling: A case-control study
column5: (a) 25 PwP+punding (15 male), 65 (8.9). UPDRS 19.3 (8.7), duration 8.1 years (4.2). (b) 130 PwP-punding (67 male), 67.2 (9.4). UPDRS 20 (8.1), duration 6.9 (5.4).
column6: Snaith-Hamilton Pleasure Scale (hedonic tone), Barratt Impulsiveness Scale
column7: PwP+punders scored higher on the BIS and motor subscale but not attention/non-planning subscales. PwP+punders scored higher on the Snaith-Hamilton Pleasure Scale, which suggests a reduced ability to gain pleasure from rewarding activities (anhedonia). (c) Both groups had additional other ICBs but punding group had significantly more.

column4: Dysfunctional inhibitory control in Parkinson’s disease patients with levodopa-induced dyskinesias
column5: (a) 14 PwP+dyskinesia (5 male), 67.5 (8.3). UPDRS ON 14.3 (3.6), UPDRS OFF 27.6 (1.6), duration 10.3 years (5.8). (b) 14 PwP-dyskinesia (9 male), 70.4 (6.1). UPDRS ON 13.9 (2.9), UPDRS OFF 26.1 (4.3), duration 7.7 years (2.5). (c) 10 HC (5 male), 68.3 (8.4).
column6: Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (impulsivity traits), Go/No-Go task (proactive motor inhibition), Stop Signal Task (reactive motor inhibition). Also: Medication ON/OFF.
column7: PwP+dyskinesias (levodopa induced) scored more impulsive on BIS than PwP-dyskinesias and HCs but no differences between PwP-dyskinesias and HCs. PwP+dyskineas had longer SSRTs than both PwP-dyskinesias and HCs, both when the patient groups were ON and OFF medication. No differences in commission errors on the GNG task between groups, regardless of whether ON or OFF medication.

column4: Executive functioning and risk-taking behavior in Parkinson's disease patients with impulse control disorders
column5: (a) 17 PwP+ICB (14 male), 55 (37-69). UPDRS 7 (0-23), duration 7 years (2-10). (b) 20 PwP-ICB (14 male), 55 (40-62). UPDRS 8.5 (0-34), duration 5.5 years (4-12). (c) 15 HC.
column6: Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (impulsivity), Conner’s Performance Test (inhibition), Trail Making Test (shifting and reactive flexibility), modified Iowa Gambling Task
column7: BIS higher in PwP+ICB than PwP-ICB group. No differences in TMT B-A scores, or commission errors on CPT. PwP+ICB and PwP-ICB chose the losing deck (higher amounts of money) more frequently than the neutral deck, and the winning deck (smaller amounts of money). PwP+ICB and PwP-ICB chose the winning deck significantly less than the HC group, but no differences for losing deck. PwP+ICB evaluated the winning deck as the loser deck more frequently than both the PwP-ICB and HC groups (more sensitive to reward than punishment?). No info available on HC group, but says they were matched by age, sex, and educational level.

column4: Subthalamic deep brain stimulation restores automatic response activation and increases susceptibility to impulsive behavior in patients with Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 13 PwP (11 male), 64.41 (6.59). UPDRS ON STN-DBS 16.31 (8.38), UPDRS OFF STN-DBS 38.15 (17.88), duration 17 years (6.03). (b) 26 HC (13 male), 65.08 (8.14).
column6: Interference task (spatial-compatibility). Also: OFF medication, STN-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: Larger spatial compatibility effect (for reaction time, not errors) when DBS was ON versus DBS was OFF. No differences in spatial compatibility effects (reaction time and errors) between HCs and PwP (whether DBS ON or OFF). Automatic response activation processes, and not inhibitory control processes, are affected by the basal ganglia in PwP.

column4: Decision Making in De Novo Parkinson's Disease
column6: Iowa Gambling Task (decision making).
column7: No differences in total score for IGT between de novo PwP and HC. Both groups learned to pick advantageously over time. IGT score not related to motor subtype (tremor dominant vs postural instability and gait dominance) or BIS total score.

column4: Alexithymia may modulate decision making in patients with de novo Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 12 de novo PwP with alexithymia (10 male), 63.92 (7.17). (b) 12 de novo PwP without alexithymia (7 male), 66.17 (5.20).
column6: Iowa Gambling Task (decision making under uncertainty).
column7: No differences in IGT total score between groups. Both groups learned to pick advantageously over time, but alexythymic patients learned to do this faster.

column4: Orienting of attention and Parkinson's disease: Tactile inhibition of return and response inhibition
column6: Tactile Inhibition of Return.
column7: The PwP group showed a significant IOR effect in the cue-target condition, but not the target-target condition. HCs showed a larger magnitude of the IOR effect compared to the PwP group.

column4: Reduced task-set inertia in Parkinson's disease
column6: Alternating Stroop Switching Task (task-set inertia, set-maintenance, cognitive inhibition).
column7: Interference effect (RT) significantly greater in PwP than HCs. Both groups had significantly longer response times for alternating lists than baseline, but did not differ between groups. Age of onset was not correlated with Stroop interference or switch costs.

column4: Space-based but not object-based inhibition of return is impaired in Parkinson's disease
column6: Inhibition of Return
column7: Object-based: No difference in IOR magnitude between HCs and PwP. Space-based: PwP demonstrated significantly smaller IOR effects (near zero) than HC.

column4: Subthalamic nucleus deep brain stimulation induces impulsive action when patients with Parkinson's disease act under speed pressure
column6: Moving Dots Task (impulsivity). Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: Under speed instructions PwP patients were faster ON than OFF STN-DBS, but under accuracy instructions RTs did not change significantly. For the HCs the RTs did not change between the instructions given. PwP patients made more errors than HCs and these were more frequent under speed instructions, especially with STN-DBS ON. PwP patients had a higher response threshold than HCs, and thus responded more cautiously. The threshold was also higher with STN-DBS OFF compared to when it was ON, and changed more significantly under speed instructions than accuracy. STN-DBS caused a decrease in levels of caution (evidenced by lowering of response threshold), i.e. higher impulsive action under speed pressure.

column4: Failed suppression of direct visuomotor activation in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 8 PwP (8 male), 58 (8). UPDRS OFF medication 37 (9), H&Y 2-3, duration 5.75 years (2.71). (b) 8 HC (8 male), 57 (5).
column6: Simon task (response inhibition/attention). Also: EEG.
column7: PwP showed less inhibitory control than HC for error rates but not RT

column4: Contextual cues remediate problem solving: Deficits in Parkinson's disease
column6: Anagram Task (self-directed cognitive flexibility), Stroop task (inhibitory control).
column7: No significant differences for RT interference between PwP and HC on Stroop task. PwP and HC similar proportion correct and similar RTs on anagram task in cued condition (some blanks filled in), but PwP significantly worse (proportion correct and RTs) in baseline condition (no cues). Stroop inhibitory control proficiency correlated with faster baseline RTs on anagram task.

column4: Dopamine Receptor D3 rs6280 is Associated with Aberrant Decision-Making in Parkinson's Disease
column5: (a) 45 PwP with genotype status CT/CC. (b) 33 PwP with genotype status TT. (NB: No additional participant info available, but they did not significantly differ in gender, age of onset, past ICB, dopamine agonist use, and total LEDD).
column6: Iowa Gambling Task (decision making under ambiguous risk)
column7: No difference between DRD3 rs6280 groups for total IGT score, or IGT block scores. TT group chose equally from all decks whereas CT/CC group showed a skewed preference for choosing deck A (disadvantageous), C (advantageous), and D (advantageous) over deck B (disadvantageous). CT/CC group demonstrated loss aversion.

column4: Impact of Specific Executive Functions on Driving Performance in People With Parkinson's Disease
column6: Stroop test (inhibition), Trail Making Test (global executive function)
column7: PwP showed a greater interference effect on Stroop than HC. No differences on Trail Making Test B-A.

column4: Decreased Ventral Striatal Activity with Impulse Control Disorders in Parkinson's Disease
column5: (a) 9 PwP+ICB (7 male), 56.2 (10.7). H&Y 2.1 (0.3), duration 7.2 years (4.4). (b) 9 PwP-ICB (8 male), 54.5 (9.6). H&Y 2.1 (0.2), duration 7.6 years (6.6).
column6: Balloon Analogue Risk Task (risk taking). Also: fMRI.
column7: No differences in adjusted pumps (or any other measure for BART) between PwP+ICB and PwP-ICB. Resting perfusion: no differences in global cerebral blood flow but PwP+ICB group showed reduced CBF in ventral striatum. PwP+ICB group had reduced activation in ventral striatum during risk taking, but no differences relating to win or loss outcomes (and this overlapped with resting perfusion).

column4: The role of the subthalamic nucleus in response inhibition: Evidence from deep brain stimulation for Parkinson's disease
column6: Stop Signal task (response inhibition). Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: STN-DBS impaired response inhibition in PwP but only if their baseline performance was similar to HCs. STN-DBS of the right side of the body had no effect on response inhibition, but on the left side it impaired response inhibition.

column4: Extrastriatal dopaminergic abnormalities of DA homeostasis in Parkinson's patients with medication-induced pathological gambling: A [11C] FLB-457 and PET study
column6: Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (trait impulsivity)
column7: Total BIS higher in PwP+PG than PwP-PG.

column4: Acting without being in control: Exploring volition in Parkinson's disease with impulsive compulsive behaviours
column6: Intentional binding task (sense of agency), Stop Signal Task (reactive inhibition), Marble task (intentional inhibition), Balloon Analogue Risk Task (reward sensitivity), Trail Making Test (executive functioning)
column7: Significant main effect of group on SSRT (impaired in PwP-ICB compared to HC) but no differences between PwP+ICB and PwP-ICB. No significant differences between groups on Marble task. No significant differences between groups on BART (risk adjustment – learning which colour balloon which riskier, and difference between inflation on low and high risk balloons). No significant differences between groups on TMT-B, but PwP (think this includes both PwP+ICB and PwP-ICB?) were slower than HC for TMT-A. Conclusion: No differences between PwP+ICB and PwP-ICB on any task and PwP-ICB worse than HC for SSRT only.

column4: Executive function in Parkinson's disease: Set-shifting or set-maintenance?
column6: Stroop task (perceptual interference), Odd Man Out test (set shifting)
column7: Worse total score for PwP than HC, even when only including switch trials only. Disruption of the first switch was more pronounced in PwP than HC, and even though both groups recovered to begin with the HCs recovered a lot better. No differences in interference effects on Stroop task.

column4: Mixing pro- and anti-saccades in patients with Parkinsonian syndromes
column5: (a) 15 PwP. (b) 8 corticobasal degeneration patients. (c) 12 progressive supranuclear palsy patients. (d) 10 HC.
column6: Pro-saccade task, Anti-saccade task, Mixed pro-saccade and anti-saccade task.
column7: No difference in inhibitory control (accuracy and RT) between PwP and HC when anti-saccade task performed separately. PwP worse when pro- and anti-saccade trials are mixed for accuracy, but not RT. When pro-saccade and anti-saccade tasks are mixed in a Go/No-Go type paradigm, inhibitory control in PwP is significantly reduced compared to HC.

column4: Dissociating executive mechanisms of task control following frontal lobe damage and Parkinson's disease
column6: Task switching paradigm (task switching)
column7: PwP showed reduced switch costs (and HC showed switch benefit) when cue was a word rather than a colour. Both PwP and HC showed greater switch costs in crosstalk versus no crosstalk conditions. RTs and error rates higher for PwP and HC when irrelevant character was task-associated rather than neutral, but no differences between groups. No differences in ability to un-inhibit previously inhibited task-associated character between PwP and HCs. No direct comparisons between HC and PwP for some.

column4: Deep brain stimulation of the subthalamic nucleus transiently enhances loss-chasing behaviour in patients with Parkinson's Disease
column6: Gambling task (loss chasing). Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: No relevant stats available for proportionate choice or value of losses. No significant differences between STN-DBS OFF and ON for mean deliberation times for deciding to chases losses or quit. Behavioural results have some missing info.

column4: Pathological Gambling in Parkinson's Disease: Subthalamic Oscillations During Economics Decisions
column5: (a) 8 PwP+PG (6 male), 57 (11.9). Duration 11 years (4.86). (b) 9 PwP-PG (3 male), 61 (6.07). Duration 10 years (2.77).
column6: Economics task (decision making). Also: EEG.
column7: (a) PwP+PG patients used a risky strategy, whereas PwP-PG did not. (b) No differences in performance between groups on trials requiring a risky decision and trials not requiring a risky decision. (c) Higher changes in low frequency power in STN when viewing trials requiring a risky decision than trials not requiring a risky decision.

column4: Decision-making in Parkinson's disease patients with and without pathological gambling
column6: Stroop task (executive functioning), Zuckerman-Kuhlman Personality Questionnaire (sensation seeking), Go/No-Go (response inhibition), Iowa Gambling Task (decision making under ambiguity), Game of Dice Task (decision making under risk), Investment Task (decision making under risk).
column7: PwP+PG selected more disadvantageously than PwP-PG for deck B (bad deck, higher immediate gains) only, and as time went on PwP+PG group didn’t develop better strategy whereas PwP-PG did. Pathological gambling affects decision making under ambiguity but not risk. No group differences for GoD, Investment task, Stroop, Go/No-Go, or Zuckerman-Kuhlman Personality Questionnaire. No group differences for Stroop (switching, and inhibition based on number of correct words within 45 seconds and number of errors)

column4: Impulsivity in Parkinson's disease is associated with alterations in affective and sensorimotor striatal networks
column5: (a) 21 PwP+ICB (14 male), 60 (5). UPDRS 25.95 (9.92), duration 57.3 months (30.7). (b) 30 PwP-ICB (19 male), 62 (8). UPDRS 25.33 (9.49), duration 44.2 months (37.7).
column6: Beads task, Barratt Impulsiveness Scale
column7: PwP+ICB group had higher total BIS scores and higher motor scores than PwP-ICB, but no significant differences for attentional or non-planning impulsivity. No significant differences between groups for number of beads drawn on 80/20 and 60/40 trials, or for $10 and $0 loss trials. Participants similarly drew more beads for 60/40 trials and $10 loss trials, and more frequently chose the correct jar for 80/20 trials. Higher BIS scores were related to reduced connectivity between the left putamen and various frontal, temporal, and cerebellar areas, between the left caudate and temporal areas, and between the left STN and frontal areas. There was a negative association between the average number of draw choices and grey matter volume in the putamen, i.e. patients who made more draw choices (less impulsivity) exhibited a smaller putamen GM value than those who collected less evidence.

column4: Relationship between poor decision-making process and fatigue perception in Parkinson's disease patients
column5: (a) 33 fatigued PwP (20 male), 61.73 (9.85). UPDRS 30.85, H&Y 2 (0.57), duration 59.30 (41.33) months. (b) 56 non-fatigued PwP (38 male), 62.64 (9.06). UPDRS 18.41 (5.82), H&Y 1.81 (0.58), duration 51.66 (43.78) months.
column6: Trail Making Test (response inhibition), Stroop task (cognitive flexibility/response inhibition), Iowa Gambling Task (decision making).
column7: No differences between fatigued and non-fatigued PwP patients on Trail Making Test B-A or Stroop task performance. Fatigued PwP patients made poorer decisions on the Iowa Gambling Task than non-fatigued PwP patients, particularly in later trials when the rules should have been more explicit.

column4: Cognitive correlates of “pure apathy” in Parkinson's disease
column6: Trail Making Test (executive functioning/shifting ability), Stroop (interference/inhibitory control).
column7: PwP+apathy performed worse for B-A on TMT, and interference on the Stroop test.

column4: A Comparison of Treatment-Seeking Behavioral Addiction Patients with and without Parkinson's Disease
column5: (a) 32 PwP with behavioural addictions (32 male), 61.7 (6.94). Duration 7.7 years (5.5). (b) 2428 HC with behavioural addictions (2428 male), 41.5 (13.4).
column6: Temperament and Character Inventory (personality), Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (impulsivity).
column7: HCs scored higher on the attentional, non-planning, and total scores on the BIS compared to PwP. PwP scored higher for reward dependence on the TCI than HCs. No significant differences for motor impulsivity (BIS) or novelty seeking and harm avoidance (TCI).

column4: No Effect of Subthalamic Deep Brain Stimulation on Intertemporal Decision-Making in Parkinson Patients
column5: (a) 8 PwP ON medication and ON STN-DBS. (b) 7 PwP ON medication and OFF STN-DBS. (c) 10 PwP OFF medication and ON STN-DBS. (d) 7 PwP OFF medication and OFF STN-DBS.
column6: Intertemporal Choice task (delay discounting), Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (impulsivity), Quick Delay Questionnaire (delay discounting), Holt-Laury task (risk attitude).
column7: There were no significant differences ON/OFF medication or STN-DBS for delay discounting. Lower BIS total scores when ON STN-DBS compared to OFF but only when ON medication.

column4: The basal ganglia and inhibitory mechanisms in response selection: Evidence from subliminal priming of motor responses in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 12 PwP (9 male), 60 (8). UPDRS OFF medication 29 (24-36). (b) 12 HCs (9 male), 58 (7).
column6: Masked Priming Compatibility task (response selection). Also: medication OFF, EEG.
column7: Similar RT compatibility effect but more compatibility errors in PwP than HCs at shorter (0ms) ISI. A reduced negative compatibility effect (i.e. a positive compatibility effect) in PwP and HCs at longer ISI (100ms), but significantly more reduced in PwP. Suggested reduced inhibition in PwP. More positive compatibility effect at longer ISI correlated positively with disease severity.

column4: Time-course of masked response priming and inhibition in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 11 PwP (7 male), 54 (7). UPDRS OFF medication 23 (8-33). (b) 11 HC (9 male), 53.6 (4.9).
column6: Masked Priming Compatibility Task. Also: medication OFF.
column7: Larger RT and error compatibility effects in PwP compared to HCs. The compatibility effect decreased with longer ISIs similarly for both PwP and HCs which suggests there aren’t any deficit inhibitory processes.

column4: Deep brain stimulation of the subthalamic nucleus modulates sensitivity to decision outcome value in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 22 STN-DBS PwP (18 male), 55 (7.5). UPDRS ON 16.91, UPDRS OFF 35.55, H&Y 1-3.
column6: Instrumental Learning of Reward and Punishment, Inter-temporal choice task (temporal discounting). Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: Performed worse (lower winnings) when ON compared to OFF. DBS-OFF more likely to switch choices after punishment than DBS-ON, but no differences for reward. Reduction in sensitivity to both reward and punishment when DBS was ON. Learning rates not altered when ON versus OFF. No differences in frequency of choosing sooner options when ON or OFF.

column4: Decisions under risk in Parkinson's disease: Preserved evaluation of probability and magnitude
column6: Vancouver Gambling Task (decision making under risk), Temperament and Character Inventory (novelty seeking). Also: Medication ON/OFF.
column7: No differences in novelty seeking scores. No differences between PwP and HC, whether ON or OFF meds, in the gain phase. In loss phase, PwP patients OFF meds more likely to avoid decisions with larger loss than HCs. No difference between HCs and PwP ON meds. No difference in gain or loss performance ON/OFF meds.

column4: Error signals in the subthalamic nucleus are related to post-error slowing in patients with Parkinson's disease
column6: Speeded flanker task. Also: Medication ON/OFF, EEG.
column7: No difference in interference effects, post-error slowing, or error corrections ON vs OFF meds. No difference in ERPs for compatible/incompatible trials for ON vs OFF meds. Significant differences for STN-ERPs between correct and incorrect incompatible trials, but no effect of ON/OFF meds.

column4: Dissecting the Effects of Disease and Treatment on Impulsivity in Parkinson's Disease
column6: Balloon Analogue Risk Task (risk taking), Temporal Discounting Task (delay discounting). Also: longitudinal, medication ON/OFF.
column7: PwP participants pumped significantly more ON than OFF meds and compared to HCs in later trials only (“experience influences repeated risky choices” – “PwP show relatively enhanced learning from reward”). Money earned was similar between groups. Longitudinal (1.5-3 years later) disease progression was associated with reduction in number of pumps and reduction in money earned. Performance in HC over time was stable. BART performance not related to meds dose (LEDD and DA LEDD), age, age at onset, BDI score, duration of illness, or gender. Discounting rates similar ON, OFF, and compared to HCs. No change in longitudinal follow up. Not related to meds dose (LEDD and DA LEDD), age, age at onset, BDI score, duration of illness, or gender.

column4: Trait Impulsivity Is Associated with the Risk of Falls in Parkinson's Disease
column5: (a) 237 PwP without falls (164 male), 65 (8). UPDRS 32 (1), H&Y 1-3. (b) 78 PwP recurrent fallers (44 male), 65 (8). UPDRS 37 (11), H&Y 1-3).
column6: Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (trait impulsivity).
column7: PwP patients who experience recurrent falls scored higher for trait impulsivity and attention impulsivity than those who do not, irrespective of disease severity. No significant differences in non-planning or motor impulsivity between PwP who experience recurrent falls and those that do not.

column4: Attentional set-shifting in Parkinson's disease patients with freezing of gait-acquisition and discrimination set learning deficits at the background?
column6: Set Shifting (rule learning and reversal), Stop Signal Task (inhibitory control)
column7: No differences in SSRT between groups. FOG associated with inability to ignore irrelevant stimuli and follow rule.

column4: Deep Brain Stimulation of the Subthalamic Nucleus Alters the Cortical Profile of Response Inhibition in the Beta Frequency Band: A Scalp EEG Study in Parkinson's Disease
column6: Stop Signal Task (response inhibition). Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: SSRT shorter ON compared to OFF STN-DBS. SSRT shorter in HCs than PwP OFF but not PwP ON.

column4: Delay Discounting of Reward and Caudate Nucleus Volume in Individuals with alpha-Synuclein Gene Duplication before and after the Development of Parkinson's Disease
column5: (a) 7 presymptomatic SNCA duplication carriers who later developed hereditary PwP (5 male), 47.7 (8.6). UPDRS 32.1 (5.2), H&Y 1-4. (b) 10 HC (7 male), 45.6 (8.2).
column6: Kirby Delayed Discounting Questionnaire. Also: longitudinal, before/after commencement of PwP symptoms, caudate nucleus volume.
column7: Prior to developing PwP, no significant differences in delay discounting between SNCA carriers and HCs. After developing PwP, significantly higher k (more impulsive) for SNCA+PwP than HC. No differences in caudate volume before developing PwP, but afterwards the SNCA+PwP group had significantly reduced caudate nucleus volumes which was significantly different to HC. Significant negative correlation between caudate volume and k.

column4: Initiation and inhibitory control of saccades with the progression of Parkinson's disease-Changes in three major drives converging on the superior colliculus
column6: Visually guided saccades, Gap visually guided saccades, Memory guided saccades, Hand reaction time task
column7: Latencies of VGS and GAP were significantly longer, and accuracy reduced, in PwP compared to HC. Same for MGS. VGS latency normal for PwP for small distances from fixation, but longer for greater distances compared to PwP. PwP had similar latencies across all distances in MGS, but all longer than HCs. MGS latency and hand RT correlated positively with disease severity, and MGS success rate correlated negatively with disease severity. VGS latency increases in stage 2 and then plateaus for stages 3-4. GAP latency increases in stage 2 then decreases again. Inadvertent saccades to the cue in the delay period and incorrect saccades to target when meant to be focused on fixation point only were positively correlated with disease stage (showing reduced inhibitory control over progression of disease). “initiation of memory guided saccades and inhibitory control of reflexive saccades deteriorated with the progress of the disease”.

column4: Reward sensitivity in Parkinson's patients with binge eating
column5: (a) 16 PwP with binge eating (8 male), 67.1 (8.2). UPDRS 20.5 (9.6) , H&Y 1.7 (0.4), duration 8.5 years (5.6). (b) 17 PwP without binge eating (8 male), 64.9 (12.9). UPDRS 15.8 (8.1), H&Y 1.7 (0.4), duration 6.8 (3.1). (c) 20 HC (10 male), 68 (6.4).
column6: Behavioural Inhibition System/Behavioural Activation Systems, Barratt Impulsiveness Scale, Trail Making Test
column7: No significant differences between groups for TMT B-A, BIS total, BIS attention, motor, or non-planning. No significant differences between groups for BAS total, BAS reward responsiveness, BAS drive. However, PwP+BE scored lower compared to HC on the BAS fun seeking subscale.

column4: Resting-state brain networks in patients with Parkinson's disease and impulse control disorders
column6: Trail Making Test, Stroop task
column7: No significant differences between groups on TMT-B or the Stroop interference effect.

column4: Impaired frontal lobe functions in patients with Parkinson's disease and psychosis
column6: FAB conflicting instructions (sensitivity to interference), FAB Go/No-Go (inhibitory control).
column7: PwP+psychosis had lower scores on both interference and inhibitory control measures compared to PwP-psychosis.

column4: Parkinson's Disease Subtypes Show Distinct Tradeoffs Between Response Initiation and Inhibition Latencies
column6: Stop Signal Task (response initiation and inhibition, with Choice Signal Task used to determine some variables), Delis-Kaplan Trail Making Test.
column7: PwP+PIGD group showed greater proactive slowing (Go-RT in choice task versus SST) compared to both PwP+TD and HC but no differences between PwP+TD and HC. Both PwP+PIGD and PwP+TD showed longer SSRTs than HC. No significant differences for TMT-B between groups.

column4: On the role of dopamine replacement therapy in decision-making, working memory, and reward in Parkinson's disease: Does the therapy-dose matter?
column6: Cambridge Gamble Task (risky decision making). Also: medication ON/OFF.
column7: No differences in quality of the decision, risk adjustment, or impulsivity ON/OFF meds. PwP significantly more impulsive and made poorer quality decisions than HC, but no differences in risk adjustment. Higher levodopa equivalent daily dose was associated with poorer quality decisions and higher impulsivity.

column4: Impulsivities and Parkinson's Disease: Delay Aversion Is Not Worsened by Deep Brain Stimulation of the Subthalamic Nucleus
column5: 21 PwP (13 male), 60 (6.2). UPDRS ON DBS 23.71 (10.8), UPDRS OFF DBS 45.31 (14.77).
column6: Cambridge Gambling task (delay aversion), Barratt Impulsiveness Scale (impulsivity), Sensitivity to Reward and Sensitivity to Punishment Questionnaire (inhibition and approach), Quick Delay Questionnaire (delay aversion and delay discounting). Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: There were no significant differences when STN-DBS was ON or OFF in terms of delay aversion, inhibition and approach, or delay discounting. When STN-DBS was ON, patients reported lower global impulsivity, but there were no significant differences in terms of attention, motor, or non-planning impulsivity.

column4: Assessment of Metacognition and Reversal Learning in Parkinson’s Disease: Preliminary Results
column6: Probabilistic Reversal Learning task (reversal learning)
column7: Mean number of trials to reach reversal: Both PwP ON and PwP OFF had a higher mean (worse performance) than HCs, but no differences ON/OFF. Number of consecutive errors after reversals: significantly higher than HC when ON, but not OFF, and no differences between ON/OFF. Random switches after positive feedback: significantly higher than HC when ON, but not OFF, and no differences between ON/OFF. Strategy change after probabilistic error: No difference ON vs OFF, but both significantly higher than HC (is this better?). RT: No significant differences. Accuracy: No significant differences. Mean confidence level: No significant differences. Meta-d: Significant positive correlation between d (stimulus discrimination sensitivity) and meta-d (metacognition type 2 sensitivity) for PwP OFF and HC but not for PwP ON. Learning rate: No significant differences. Mean values of decision making parameter: deterministic decision making for HCs, and exploratory decision making for PwP (ON and OFF).

column4: Unimpaired negative but enhanced positive priming in Parkinson's disease: Evidence from an identity and a location priming task
column6: Identity Priming/Flanker Task (positive/negative priming), Location Priming Task (positive/negative priming)
column7: Both PwP and HCs displayed similar NP effects in the location priming task but neither displayed a NP effect in the identity priming task. Greater magnitude of PP in PwP than HCs for both location and identity priming tasks.

column4: To the influence of general slowing and medication on identity- and location-based priming effects in patients with Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 20 PwP OFF medication (13 male), 63.4 (9.3, 46-77). UPDRS ON 24.6 (15.1), duration 4.6 years (5.2). (b) 20 medicated PwP (9 male), 63.6 (10.4, 37-76). UPDRS ON 25.4 (14.7), duration 4.9 years (4.9). (c) 20 HC (10 male), 64.4 (10.9, 39-85).
column6: Identity Priming/Flanker Task (positive/negative priming), Location Priming Task (positive/negative priming).
column7: Identity priming NP – reduced in medicated PwP but similar for unmedicated PwP and HCs. Location priming NP – all groups similar. dentity priming PP – all groups similar (but needed to be controlled for general slowing otherwise HC seemed to show smaller identity PP). Location priming PP – all groups similar (but needed to be controlled for general slowing otherwise HC seemed to show smaller location PP).

column4: Stimulation of the subthalamic region facilitates the selection and inhibition of motor responses in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 17 PwP with STN-DBS. (b) 15 PwP (n = 5) or essential tremor (n = 10) patients with DBS of the ventral intermediate nucleus of the thalamus.
column6: Go/No-Go, Stop Signal task. Also: STN-DBS ON/OFF, Vim-DBS ON/OFF.
column7: STN-DBS increased response speed but did not affect accuracy (Go/No-Go task). STN-DBS improves inhibitory control on the Stop Signal task, and is not due to a global increase in the speed of responding.

column4: Overriding actions in parkinson's disease: Impaired stopping and changing of motor responses
column6: Stop-Change Paradigm (action stopping and initiation)
column7: SSRT was longer for PwP compared to HC. PwP were slower to initiate change response than HC. PwP were slower than HC to respond following a Stop trial when the arrow stimulus pointed the opposite way (difficulty decoupling stimulus association from stop-change).

column4: Impaired control of the oculomotor reflexes in Parkinson's disease
column6: Prosaccade/antisaccade task (control of oculomotor reflexes).
column7: PwP made more errors overall than HC, but this didn’t depend on whether it was a pro-/anti-saccade. No significant group differences for latency between pro- and anti-saccades. PwP have reduced cortical control than HCs (difference between fixation offset effect in pro vs antisaccades).

column4: Don't look now or look away: Two sources of saccadic disinhibition in Parkinson's disease?
column6: Prosaccade/antisaccade/delayed saccade
column7: No significant effect of group (PwP or HC) on latencies in antisaccade task. PwP showed larger gap effect (latency for no gap minus latency for gap) in prosaccade but smaller in antisaccade compared to HC. Express saccades in prosaccade: both groups made more express saccades with a gap than without a gap. PwP made more express saccades than HC (mostly driven by gap trials). PwP group made more errors than HC. No differences in type of error (directional or timing) or interaction between type of error and group. Direction errors in the antisaccade task were positively correlated with express saccades in the prosaccade task. Refutes unitary model of eye movement deficits as measures weren’t correlated with each other mostly.

column4: Dissociable Effects of Dopamine on the Initial Capture and the Reactive Inhibition of Impulsive Actions in Parkinson's Disease
column6: Simon task (impulsive response capture/inhibitory control). Also: Medication ON/OFF.
column7: No difference between PwP and HC for impulsive response capture. Reduced response inhibition for PwP compared to HC. Response inhibition in PwP significantly improved by medication, but still reduced compared to HC.

column4: Speed pressure in conflict situations impedes inhibitory action control in Parkinson's disease
column5: (a) 21 PwP (13 male), 63.5. UPDRS 12.8, duration 6 years. (b) 21 HC (13 male), 62.9.
column6: Simon task (impulsive response capture/inhibitory control). Also: EEG.
column7: When encouraged to prioritise speed of responding, PwP and HC have similar Simon effects for both RT and accuracy. When encouraged to prioritise accuracy of responding the Simon effect for RT was greater in PwP compared to HCs but the accuracy interference effect was the same. CAFs: PwP and HC were equally likely to produce impulsive errors regardless of correspondence or whether emphasising speed or accuracy. Delta plots: final slope didn’t differ between HC and PwP when accuracy was emphasised but was significantly more negative going in HC than PwP when speed was emphasised (better response inhibition).

column4: Freezing of Gait in Parkinson Disease Is Associated With Impaired Conflict Resolution
column6: Attention Network Test (conflict resolution/executive control). Also: Medication ON/OFF.
column7: In the ON phase, PwP+FOG showed reduced conflict resolution compared to PwP-FOG but not HCs (insufficient power). No difference between PwP-FOG and HCs. No effects of medication.

column4: Conflict and Freezing of Gait in Parkinson's Disease: Support for a Response Control Deficit
column6: Attention Network Test (conflict resolution/executive control), Stroop task (conflict resolution).
column7: PwP+FOG showed reduced conflict resolution (executive control) on ANT compared to PwP-FOG and HCs but No difference between PwP-FOG and HCs. No difference in error rates or Stroop effects between groups on the Stroop task. PwP+FOG showed more fast errors on the ANT compared to HCs but no differences between PwP-FOG and either group. PwP+FOG and PwP-FOG showed more fast errors on the Stroop task compared to HCs. No differences between PwP+FOG and PwP-FOG. No differences in response suppression between groups on the ANT or Stroop task.

column4: Responsiveness to distracting stimuli, though increased in Parkinson's disease, is decreased in asymptomatic PINK1 and Parkin mutation carriers
column5: (a) 12 PwP (9 male), 64.92 (50-79). UPDRS 19.33 (8.41), H&Y 2.13 (0.57), duration 4.08 years (3.37). (b) 13 OC (4 male), 68 (55-75). (c) 19 Asymptomatic Parkin and PINK1 mutation carriers (13 male), 41 (31-50). (d) 13 YC (5 male), 42 (31-50).
column6: Eriksen flanker task (responsiveness to distracting stimuli). Also: EEG.
column7: No differences in the RT flanker effect between PwP and OCs except when flankers presented simultaneously with the target (instead of a lag), where PwPs were more susceptible.

column4: Patterns of Eye Movement Impairment Correlate with Regional Brain Atrophy in Neurodegenerative Parkinsonism
column5: (a) 39 PwP (23 male), 72 (43-84). UPDRS 31 (4-60), H&Y 3 (1-5), duration 7 years (1-22). (b) 24 HC (15 male), 66 (48-79). (c) 32 progressive supranuclear palsy. (d) 18 multiple system atrophy
column6: Smooth pursuit, Visually guided reactive saccades. Also: MRI.
